readingAnalyses.title: Fall of the Ming
readingAnalyses.author: Various (Song Yingxing, Li Zicheng broadsheet, court documents)
readingAnalyses.summary: A collection of late Ming primary sources documenting the dynasty's collapse from multiple perspectives: Song Yingxing's cyclical philosophy of history and analysis of fiscal crisis, rebel Li Zicheng's propaganda justifying uprising, and accounts of the brutal rebel Zhang Xianzhong. These documents reveal both elite and popular explanations for Ming decline, centering on fiscal crisis, corrupt governance, and the suffering of common people.

keyQuotes.quote: When order is at its peak, chaos results; when chaos is at its peak, order results.
Today, people are killed by bandit mobs; tomorrow, they may die at the hands of government troops.

The fatuous and self-indulgent Emperor of the Ming dynasty was not humane. He spoiled his eunuchs, relied heavily on exam graduates, was greedy for taxes and levies, used harsh punishments, and could not save the people from calamities.
To control Zhang is easy but to control Li is difficult. This is because people fear Zhang Xianzhong while people are siding with Li Zicheng.

thematicExamples: Salt merchants bankrupted by excessive taxation - their capital dropped from 30 million to 5 million taels between Wanli and Tianqi eras, illustrating fiscal extractionism
Li Zicheng's propaganda promising discipline ('Any battalion that kills good people without permission will be executed') versus Zhang Xianzhong's pure terror ('appointed by Heaven to kill')
The story of Ge Xian who volunteered for execution to save his community from collective punishment - illustrating local self-sacrifice
realLifeConnections: The contrast between Li Zicheng (ideological rebel) and Zhang Xianzhong (pure warlord) parallels modern debates about revolutionary movements vs. criminal insurgencies
Song Yingxing's cyclical view of history ('when chaos is at its peak, order is coming') resonates with contemporary discussions of whether crises create opportunities for reform
The fiscal squeeze on salt merchants mirrors modern debates about overtaxation driving economic collapse and social unrest

readingAnalyses.title: SHI Kefa's Letters / The Massacre of Yangzhou
readingAnalyses.author: Shi Kefa, Wang Xiuchu
readingAnalyses.source: Struve, Voices from the Ming-Qing Cataclysm
readingAnalyses.summary: Shi Kefa's farewell letters to his family on the eve of Yangzhou's fall reveal the agonizing choices facing Ming loyalists: duty to a fallen dynasty versus responsibility to family and the people under their protection. Wang Xiuchu's harrowing survivor account of the ten-day massacre demonstrates the brutal consequences of resistance, with Dodo authorizing five days of unrestrained killing and rape as an example to other cities.

keyQuotes.quote: In eighteen years of official service, I have tasted every bitterness and yet been unable to increase the welfare of the court. I have only been vastly remiss in attending to my parents. Neither effectively loyal nor filial, how can I show my face in the world?
Kefa is about to die. I made a pact with you, my wife, that we would wait for one another in the grave.
Sooner or later I must die, and I wonder whether my wife is willing to follow me? In a world like this, life is of no use anyway.
To repay the nation with this one death is surely my destiny. I only regret not having earlier followed our former emperor to the grave.

thematicExamples: Shi Kefa arranging for his military aide Shi Dewei to fulfill filial duties after his death - showing how loyalist martyrdom required complex family arrangements
The expectation that Shi's wife would follow him in death - illustrating gender expectations during the Ming-Qing transition
Wang Xiuchu's account of men helpless against martial might, relying only on mutual aid among brothers
realLifeConnections: The tension between public duty and private obligation resonates with modern debates about work-life balance and professional sacrifice
The ethics of resistance when it will bring suffering to civilians parallels contemporary debates about asymmetric warfare and civilian casualties
Shi Kefa's expectation that his wife die for chastity raises questions about historical gender norms and their persistence

readingAnalyses.title: Rise of Qing
readingAnalyses.author: Various (Nurhaci, Wu Sangui, Dorgon)
readingAnalyses.summary: Documents tracing the Manchu rise from Nurhaci's 1618 'Seven Grievances' through the pivotal Wu Sangui-Dorgon alliance of 1644 to Dorgon's letters demanding submission. These sources reveal Manchu strategic brilliance in combining military pressure with political inducements, framing conquest as revenge for the Ming emperor's death rather than foreign invasion, while the hair-cutting edicts symbolized the ultimate demand for cultural submission.

keyQuotes.quote: Since the time of our ancestors, we have overseen the border region for the great Ming dynasty... The insults, invasions, damage, and suffering that have resulted are indescribable!
Our state, in its pacification of Peking, seized it from the 'Dashing Bandit' Li Zicheng and not from the Ming state.
If your excellence is willing to lead your troops to us, we will enfoeff you with a domain and ennoble you as a prince.
Those who follow this order belong to our country; those who hesitate will be considered treasonous bandits.
Lose your hair or lose your head (Liutou bu liufa, liufa bu liutou)

thematicExamples: Nurhaci's grievances as political manifesto - transforming tribal complaints into justification for conquest
Wu Sangui's defection: offered princely title and domain in exchange for opening Shanhaiguan pass
The hair-cutting decree as symbolic submission: 'The Emperor is like the father and the people are like his sons... how can they be different from one another?'
realLifeConnections: Nurhaci's 'Seven Grievances' model follows a pattern seen in modern declarations of independence (American Declaration, etc.) - listing wrongs to justify rebellion
Wu Sangui's pragmatic switching of allegiances parallels modern debates about collaborators and defectors in wartime
The queue/hair-cutting decree as forced cultural assimilation parallels colonial policies worldwide and modern debates about minority cultural rights

overallSynthesis:
These three readings together tell the story of dynastic transition as a multi-dimensional catastrophe: fiscal, military, moral, and cultural. The Fall of the Ming documents reveal a dynasty collapsing from within - overtaxation bankrupting merchants, rebel armies emerging from peasant desperation, government troops as predatory as bandits. Song Yingxing's philosophical observation that 'when chaos is at its peak, order results' provides an elite framework for understanding collapse, while Li Zicheng's broadsheet shows how rebels justified themselves by promising to end the very abuses that Song documented.

Shi Kefa's letters and the Yangzhou massacre reveal the human cost of loyalism. Shi embodies the Confucian ideal of loyalty unto death, yet his martyrdom brought catastrophic consequences for Yangzhou's civilians - the five-day massacre was explicitly designed as an 'example' for other cities. This raises uncomfortable questions about the ethics of resistance: was Shi's principled stand worth the lives of tens of thousands?

The Rise of Qing documents show how the Manchus brilliantly exploited Ming weaknesses. Nurhaci's grievances established a narrative of justified rebellion; Dorgon's letters to Wu Sangui and Shi Kefa offered the carrot of titles and domains while threatening the stick of annihilation. The hair-cutting edict transformed conquest into cultural transformation - to keep one's hair was to reject the new order entirely. Together, these readings show that dynastic change was not just political but involved fundamental transformations in identity, loyalty, and survival strategies for millions of people.

keywords.definition: The violent transition period (1644-1683) when the Manchu Qing dynasty conquered and consolidated control over Ming China
keywords.relevance: Central framework for understanding the period's violence and moral dilemmas

keywords.definition: Rebel armies like those of Li Zicheng and Zhang Xianzhong that emerged from famine and oppression in northwestern China
keywords.relevance: Key actors who weakened Ming defenses and enabled Manchu conquest

keywords.definition: Nurhaci's 1618 declaration of war against the Ming, listing seven complaints justifying Manchu rebellion
keywords.relevance: Foundation document of Manchu state-building and ideological justification for conquest

keywords.definition: Manchu hairstyle requiring shaved forehead and braided back, imposed on Chinese subjects as sign of submission
keywords.relevance: Symbol of conquest and cultural transformation; resistance meant death

keywords.definition: Collective term for rump Ming governments established by loyalists after 1644 (Hongguang, Longwu, Yongli emperors)
keywords.relevance: Context for Shi Kefa's resistance and continued loyalist struggles

people: Nurhaci (1559-1626) - Founder of Manchu state, issued Seven Grievances
Dorgon (1612-1650) - Manchu regent, architect of conquest strategy
Wu Sangui (1612-1678) - Ming general who opened Shanhaiguan to Manchus
Shi Kefa (1602-1645) - Ming loyalist martyr, died defending Yangzhou
Zhang Xianzhong (1605-1647) - Brutal rebel warlord, ravaged Sichuan
places: Yangzhou - Wealthy Grand Canal city, site of 1645 massacre
Shanhaiguan - Strategic pass where Wu Sangui admitted Manchu forces
Nanjing - Southern capital, seat of Hongguang emperor's rump court
Beijing/Peking - Capital captured by Li Zicheng April 1644, then by Manchus June 1644
things: Queue/Bianzi - Mandated Manchu hairstyle symbolizing submission
Salt Gabelle - Government salt monopoly, key revenue source bankrupted by overtaxation
Veritable Records (Shilu) - Official dynastic chronicles compiled each reign

keyQuestions.question: Why did ordinary people sometimes prefer rebel leaders like Li Zicheng to Ming government forces?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Both rebel and government armies looted and killed; Li promised relief from taxes and discipline; 'the people looked upon the bandits as their benefactors'; government troops drove people to rebellion

keyQuestions.question: Was Shi Kefa's martyrdom at Yangzhou morally justified, given that his resistance led to the massacre of tens of thousands of civilians?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Loyalist duty vs. responsibility to civilians; Dodo explicitly used Yangzhou as 'example' for other cities; did other cities surrender faster because of the massacre?; ethics of resistance when civilians bear the cost

keyQuestions.question: How did the Manchus transform conquest into a narrative of righteous revenge rather than foreign invasion?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Claimed to avenge Chongzhen emperor killed by rebels; 'seized Peking from Li Zicheng, not from Ming'; offered continuity (titles, positions) to those who submitted; framed Ming loyalists as the real rebels

keyQuestions.question: What did the queue decree reveal about Manchu intentions for ruling China?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Not just political but cultural submission required; 'father and sons of the same body'; resistance = treason; contrast with earlier promises not to change customs; symbolic transformation of Chinese identity

timeline.event: Nurhaci founds Later Jin (後金) in Manchuria
Nurhaci issues Seven Grievances, declares war on Ming
Manchu victory at Battle of Sarhu — Ming army destroyed
First Manchu invasion of Korea (정묘호란)
Hong Taiji renames dynasty 'Qing' (大清); invades Korea again
Joseon submits at Samjŏndo — King Injo performs three kneelings, nine prostrations
Li Zicheng captures Beijing; Chongzhen Emperor hangs himself on Coal Hill
Wu Sangui opens Shanhai Pass to Dorgon; combined forces defeat Li Zicheng
Manchu forces enter Beijing — 'Year of Three Emperors'
Yangzhou Massacre — Dodo authorizes ten days of killing as 'example'
Queue edict: 'Keep your hair, lose your head; keep your head, lose your hair'
Kangxi Emperor ascends throne (age 7)
Yongli Emperor (last Ming pretender) executed in Yunnan
Revolt of the Three Feudatories — Wu Sangui rebels, eventually crushed
Qing conquers Taiwan from Zheng (Koxinga) family — Ming loyalism ends
Treaty of Nerchinsk with Russia — first equal treaty with European power
Qing intervention in Tibet; Lhasa brought under imperial influence
Yongzheng Emperor succeeds Kangxi
Qianlong Emperor begins 60-year reign
Conquest of Xinjiang — Dzungar Khanate destroyed, empire doubles in size
Qing at maximum extent: China, Manchuria, Mongolia, Tibet, Xinjiang, Taiwan — largest Chinese empire ever

connections.fromPrevious: Plate 4 covered the Imjin War (1592-1598) when Japan invaded Korea. The Ming's costly intervention to save Joseon weakened imperial finances - setting the stage for the fiscal crisis and military weakness that enabled both the internal rebellions and Manchu conquest covered in Plate 5.
connections.toNext: Plate 6 will examine Qing's first major encounter with the West through the Macartney Mission (1793). Students should note how the confident, assertive Qing state that emerges from conquest will later struggle to adapt to Western pressure.
connections.broaderThemes: The Ming-Qing transition exemplifies the course's central themes: how internal crisis enables external conquest; how 'modernity' often arrives through violence; how ordinary people navigate between competing authorities; how cultural identity becomes politicized during regime change.

teachingNotes: Students may confuse the many rebel leaders - emphasize the Li Zicheng (ideological) vs. Zhang Xianzhong (terror) contrast
The queue decree often surprises students - connect to modern examples of forced cultural assimilation
Shi Kefa's expectation that his wife die may disturb students - use as entry point for discussing gender and loyalty norms
The 'chaos/order' cyclical view contrasts with linear Western notions of progress - good discussion point
Consider showing a map of the conquest (Beijing -> Nanjing -> Yangzhou) to help students visualize the Manchu advance
Wu Sangui's defection can generate debate: traitor or pragmatist? His later rebellion against Qing adds complexity
The Yangzhou massacre numbers (tens of thousands) should be contextualized but not minimized
Use the Zhang Xianzhong 'Gathering heads for a party' anecdote sparingly - it's vivid but horrifying
